author: Richard Jonson.
title: Stand-Up Pouches Market to reach USD 54.8 billion by 2032, growing at 8.6% CAGR
text: What are stand-up pouches? These are multi-layer laminated bags designed to stand upright on their own, widely used for their versatility and unique aesthetic appeal. The global market, valued at USD 24.2 billion in 2022, is projected to soar to USD 54.8 billion by 2032. Stand-up pouches are increasingly popular in food and beverage, pet food, cosmetics, and pharmaceutical sectors. Their design often includes a reclosable zipper or spout, enhancing user convenience. The ability to print high-quality graphics on these pouches allows companies to showcase their products with attractive packaging designs. Download Sample Report Copy Of This Report From Here: [www.amecoresearch.com/sample/276912](http://url.whate.ch/1i3zo) Key Points and Statistics on the Stand-Up Pouches Market: - The market is expected to grow from USD 24.2 billion in 2022 to USD 54.8 billion by 2032, at a CAGR of 8.6%. - Stand-up pouches are favored for their lower environmental impact compared to rigid packaging options. - They offer exceptional barrier capabilities, extending product shelf life and reducing the need for preservatives. - Market segmentation includes product type (standard, aseptic, retort, hot-filled), material type (plastic, paper, metal, bioplastic), and closure (tear notch, zipper, spout). - Key applications span across food & beverages, pet food, healthcare, personal care & cosmetics, and homecare. Stand-Up Pouches Market Overview and Analysis: Stand-up pouches are not just packaging; they are a testament to innovation in the packaging industry. Their adaptability and eco-friendly nature make them a preferred choice in a variety of sectors. The market is driven by the rising consumer demand for convenient and sustainable packaging options. However, challenges such as fluctuating raw material costs and environmental concerns over plastic use could impact market growth. Latest Stand-Up Pouches Market Trends and Innovations The stand-up pouch market is constantly evolving, with new trends and innovations emerging all the time. Some of the latest trends include: - Sustainable materials: There is a growing demand for sustainable packaging materials, and stand-up pouches are no exception. Manufacturers are increasingly using recyclable and biodegradable materials, such as paperboard and bio-based plastics. - Multi-layer structures: Stand-up pouches are often made with multi-layer structures, which can provide enhanced barrier protection against moisture, oxygen, and light. This can help to extend product shelf life and improve product quality. - Convenient designs: Stand-up pouches are designed to be convenient for consumers. They are easy to open and reseal, and they can be stored upright, which helps to prevent spills. - Customized designs: Stand-up pouches can be customized to meet the specific needs of brands. They can be printed with logos, images, and other branding elements. Major Growth Drivers of the Stand-Up Pouches Market The stand-up pouch market is driven by a number of factors, including: - Increasing demand for eco-friendly packaging: Consumers are increasingly demanding eco-friendly packaging, and stand-up pouches are a good option. They are made from recyclable and biodegradable materials, which can help to reduce environmental impact. - Need for extending product shelf life: Stand-up pouches can help to extend product shelf life by providing enhanced barrier protection. This is important for food and beverage products, as well as healthcare and cosmetic products. - Rising popularity of e-commerce: Stand-up pouches are well-suited for e-commerce applications. They are lightweight and easy to ship, and they can be stored upright, which helps to prevent spills. Key Challenges Facing the Stand-Up Pouches Industry The stand-up pouches industry faces a number of challenges, including: - Volatility in raw material prices: The price of raw materials, such as paperboard and plastics, can fluctuate significantly. This can make it difficult for manufacturers to plan their production and pricing. - Regulatory hurdles: There are a number of regulatory hurdles that can impact the stand-up pouches industry. These include regulations related to the use of plastics, as well as regulations related to the safety of food and beverage products. - Environmental concerns: There is growing concern about the environmental impact of plastics. This can lead to consumer backlash against stand-up pouches, which are often made from plastic. To Check Complete [Toc](http://url.whate.ch/1i3zl) Here: CHAPTER 1. author: @nancywestnews
title: Quick Fix Won't Overturn Injunction Blocking Divisive Concepts Law, Panel Told | InDepthNH.org
text:
By GARRY RAYNO, InDepthNH.org
CONCORD â€” A bill to add a teacherâ€™s mental state to the state divisive concepts law is not enough to overturn the federal courtâ€™s injunction, a House committee was told Wednesday.
Senate Bill 100 would add the phrase a teacher would have to â€œintentionally or knowinglyâ€ violate the law to be guilty of breaking the law.
The prime sponsor of the bill which passed the Senate on a partisan 16-8 vote, Sen. Timothy Lang, R-Sanbornton, told the House Education Policy and Administration Committee Wednesday, the bill would fix the issue raised by the federal judge in finding the stateâ€™s law unconstitutionally vague.
He said like in many other instances, the state would have to find the teacher intentionally or knowingly violated the law.
â€œIt puts the onerous back on the state if there is a complaint,â€ Lang said.
But Ian Huyett, attorney and assistant director of Cornerstone Action, said simply adding the phrase would not be enough to overturn the judgeâ€™s injunction and objection to the law.
He said the judge mentioned the issue at the end of his decision, but the bulk of his objection was the question of affirmative action and if teachers could discern what is forbidden under the law.
U.S. District Judge Paul J. Barbadoro ruled the law was unconstitutionally vague and in violation of the First Amendment. He wrote the content of the lawâ€™s measures â€œforce teachers to guess as to which diversity efforts can be touted and which must be repudiated, gambling with their careers in the process.â€
â€œWe need to do more to get the law up and running,â€Huyett said.
The stateâ€™s appeal of Barbadoroâ€™s ruling was heard at the First Circuit Court of Appeals Tuesday.
Huyett told the committee the Department of Education did not investigate one complaint filed under the law and the Department of Justice did not enforce the law believing the Human Rights Commission had to first rule on a complaint before the education department could investigate.
Huyett said his organization helped people who believe there were violations of the law file complaints, but under questioning by committee members, said they did not have a client-attorney relationship, but assisted with complaint filings.
He said most of the complaints stemmed from information on school district websites about teaching white privilege or that white privilege is racist which are clear violations of the law.
During the hearing, members of the committee quizzed Lang over situations teachers might find themselves in while teaching history or social studies or health and whether they would be in jeopardy.
Lang repeatedly said the law allows teaching historical facts and within that context nothing would put a teacherâ€™s job at risk.
Questions concerned racism as well as gender identity issues as well as current events such as the war between Israel and Palestinians.
Lang several times noted teachers are highly educated and they know the difference between facts and opinions and what is discriminatory like teaching all white people are racists.
Rep. Peggy Balboni, D-Rye Beach, noted the technical advisory by the Department of Education is vague and does not necessarily inform teachers what is acceptable and what is not.
Would the line be crossed, would you be able to have an honest discussion about slavery or racism or ask a student to put themselves in the role of a slave, and not be able to feel you could be accused of a violation, she asked.
Lang said as long as you are teaching in context, he did not see where a teacher could be accused of a violation.
He said the law has four measures as long as you are teaching within context there should not be a violation.
They would all think it was a bad idea to teach someone to treat someone differently based on race or gender, he said, noting the concepts are pretty clear.
â€œTeachers are well educated and they should be able to navigate this,â€ Lang said.
He pressed about the concerns raised by his constituents and said one concerned a teacher saying Israel was wrong in the war with Palestine and that could be construed as antisemitism.
No one testified against the bill at the public hearing, although the electronic system registered 199 people opposing the bill and four supporting it.
James Hiltz of Pembroke wrote â€œThis bill has been twisted from its original intent, to repeal the frankly unconstitutional â€˜banned conceptsâ€™ bill, to simply try and circumvent other deterrents and push our government into punishing teachers for pushing back against the limitations on them actually educating students on a complete and honest history of our country. It seems that the sponsors of this bill would rather use legislative trickery to try and force their beliefs on our school systems, rather than actually consider what the laws currently say about such matters, to force their own view of history on students rather than looking at things objectively.â€
The committee did not make an immediate recommendation on the bill.
Committee chair Rep. Glenn Cordelli, R-Tuftonboro, told Lang the House had passed a similar bill dealing with the federal court decision that is now before the Senate.
Garry Rayno may be reached at garry.rayno@yahoo.com .

organizations.name: House Education Policy and Administration Committee

author: Esther Bower
title: â€˜Remarkable new dataâ€™: NASA launching new PACE satellite to collect more precise weather, climate data
text: NASA is gearing up for its upcoming mission focused on tracking the climate and even helping save sea cows. The new payload is called PACE which stands for Plankton, Aerosol, Cloud, and Ocean Ecosystem. It will launch off the Space Coast later this month. On Wednesday, the high-tech tool was in a clean room at Astrotech in Titusville before being taken out to the launchpad, and FOX 35 saw a behind-the-scenes look at the satellite engineers created. The PACE mission is made up of 3 different instruments and took scientists nearly two decades to perfect. "Itâ€™s going to be great to finally get this mission into space and start getting the huge volume of remarkable new data that weâ€™ve never had before," said Brian Cairns whoâ€™s a deputy project scientist with the mission. The data they collect will help us here in central Florida when it comes to saving manatees because the mission will help scientists see what areas are able to grow seagrass. "We really hope to be able to support not only the teeny tiny life in the ocean but also big and beautiful ones such as manatees," said Ivona Cetinic whoâ€™s a phytoplankton ecologist focused on studying marine life in the project. Image 1 of 4 â–¼ Scientists will see entire images of the globe every two days, and thatâ€™s a big deal when it comes to getting ahead of harmful algal blooms. "We can know early on if thereâ€™s a bad bloom coming, so you can prevent deaths, prevent loss of money and things like that. PACE is going to be able to differentiate bad guys from the good guys," she added. It will also help support more precise air quality forecasts. One of the instruments collects light and analyzes the unique colors of the ocean. "Because this ocean and color instrument gives you all of the colors of light, that tells you how you high particles are in the atmosphere. You know how high smoke or pollution is, and thatâ€™s critical for air quality," said Cairns. All the data they collect will be available to the public. Cetinic hopes local leaders will tap into the new technology and "work in a better way to protect and conserve their ecosystem." This mission is set to launch in January, and NASA says it will collect data for at least three years.

title: Sophie Scholl : rÃ©sistante engagÃ©e contre le rÃ©gime nazi allemand
text:
Câ€™Ã©tait une enfant joyeuse, qui adorait la nature et se montrait amicale et serviable envers les gens. Sophie Scholl, quatriÃ¨me enfant de Lina et de Robert Scholl, vit le jour le 9 mai 1921 Ã  Forchtenberg, une petite ville de lâ€™actuel Bade-Wurtemberg. Son pÃ¨re Ã©tait maire et sa mÃ¨re, une ancienne infirmiÃ¨re communale, tenait le mÃ©nage. Les parents attachaient beaucoup dâ€™importance Ã  lâ€™Ã©ducation et Ã  lâ€™autonomie ; par ailleurs, Lina Scholl transmettait aux enfants des valeurs chrÃ©tiennes.
En 1930, la famille Scholl dÃ©mÃ©nagea Ã  Ludwigsburg et, deux ans plus tard, ils sâ€™installÃ¨rent Ã  Ulm, ville dans laquelle Robert Scholl ouvrit un cabinet fiscal. Lâ€™annÃ©e 1933, lorsque les nazis prirent le pouvoir en Allemagne, les cinq frÃ¨res et sÅ“urs Scholl, Inge, Hans, Elisabeth, Sophie et Werner, furent pris dans lâ€™engrenage du nouveau rÃ©gime. Contre la volontÃ© de leurs parents, ils sâ€™inscrivirent aux Jeunesses hitlÃ©riennes. Ã€ tout juste 13 ans, Sophie prÃªta Ã©galement serment de fidÃ©litÃ© Ã  Adolf Hitler. Cependant, ce nâ€™Ã©tait pas une Â« jeune fille Â» sage ; elle Ã©tait plutÃ´t considÃ©rÃ©e comme inadaptÃ©e, sauvage et romantique. Ses journaux intimes rÃ©vÃ¨lent une adolescente dÃ©sespÃ©rÃ©e, agitÃ©e et qui voulait sortir de ses gonds.
Sophie Scholl aimait lâ€™art moderne et la littÃ©rature Ã€ 16 ans, Sophie Scholl tomba amoureuse dâ€™un Ã©lÃ¨ve-officier de quatre ans son aÃ®nÃ©, Fritz Hartnagel, qui devint son premier ami. La correspondance dÃ©taillÃ©e du couple rÃ©vÃ¨le comment Sophie Ã©volua : elle devint une jeune femme rÃ©flÃ©chie, tenant Ã  ce que ses doutes et sa recherche dâ€™une vie appropriÃ©e soient pris au sÃ©rieux. Câ€™est durant ces annÃ©es quâ€™elle sâ€™est dÃ©tournÃ©e du systÃ¨me nazi : elle trouvait injuste lâ€™arrestation temporaire de ses frÃ¨res et sÅ“urs pour Â« BÃ¼ndische Umtriebe Â» et oppressante la restriction de la libertÃ© intellectuelle en Allemagne. Sophie Scholl aimait lâ€™art moderne et la littÃ©rature, et ne comprenait pas la conception nationale-socialiste restrictive de lâ€™art.

Au dÃ©but de la Seconde Guerre mondiale, Sophie prit clairement position et Ã©crivit Ã  Fritz Hartnagel : Â« Je nâ€™arrive pas Ã  comprendre que la vie des gens soit dÃ©sormais sous la menace constante dâ€™autres gens. Je ne le comprendrai jamais, et je trouve Ã§a terrible. Ne me dis pas que câ€™est au nom de la patrie. Â» AprÃ¨s avoir obtenu son Â« Abitur Â», elle suivit une formation dâ€™Ã©ducatrice Ã  Ulm. Lorsquâ€™elle fut ensuite contrainte, loin de sa famille et de ses amis, de faire un an de Service du travail obligatoire du Reich, une crise profonde sâ€™ensuivit. En 1941, Sophie Scholl remit tout en question : sa foi, son amour pour Fritz et sa propre maniÃ¨re dâ€™agir, qui lui semblait trop peu cohÃ©rente.
Ã‰tudes de philosophie et de biologie Ã  Munich Pleine dâ€™espoir, elle commenÃ§a en 1942 Ã  Munich des Ã©tudes de philosophie et de biologie. Elle fut aussi chaleureusement accueillie par le cercle dâ€™amis de son frÃ¨re Hans, qui vivait Ã©galement dans cette ville. Mais bien que Sophie avait tant attendu cette vie dâ€™Ã©tudiante, elle ne pouvait guÃ¨re en profiter. La dictature et la guerre pesaient trop pour elle. Son sentiment de devoir faire quelque chose contre le rÃ©gime de lâ€™injustice grandissait de jour en jour. Lorsquâ€™en juin et juillet 1942, Hans Scholl et Alexander Schmorell rÃ©digÃ¨rent les premiers tracts de la Rose blanche , appelant Ã  la rÃ©sistance contre la dictature nazie, pour Sophie Scholl, une chose Ã©tait claire : elle allait, elle aussi, sâ€™engager dans la rÃ©sistance .
En Allemagne, de nombreuses rues portent le nom de Sophie Scholl. Â© dpa/pa Il est trÃ¨s probable que les frÃ¨res et sÅ“urs Hans et Sophie Scholl aient parlÃ© des projets de tracts. DÃ¨s mai 1942, Sophie demanda Ã  son ami Fritz Hartnagel de lâ€™argent et un bulletin de dÃ©livrance pour se procurer un Â« duplicateur Â». Fritz jugea cette demande dangereuse. Il la mit en garde que cela pourrait lui Â« coÃ»ter la vie Â». MalgrÃ© lâ€™avertissement, Sophie Scholl intÃ©gra dÃ¨s janvier 1943 le cÅ“ur interne de la Â« Rose blanche Â», aux cÃ´tÃ©s de Hans Scholl, Alexander Schmorell, Willi Graf, Christoph Probst et du professeur Kurt Huber.
Je suis toujours dâ€™avis dâ€™avoir fait la seule chose que je pouvais faire pour mon peuple. Sophie Scholl Partager Overlay schlieÃŸen Twitter Facebook Telegram Whatsapp E-Mail Le matin du 18 fÃ©vrier 1943, Sophie et Hans Scholl furent dÃ©couverts et arrÃªtÃ©s alors quâ€™ils distribuaient des tracts Ã  lâ€™universitÃ© de Munich. InterrogÃ©e par la Gestapo, Sophie dÃ©fendit son action : Â« Je suis toujours dâ€™avis dâ€™avoir fait la seule chose que je pouvais faire pour mon peuple. Je ne regrette donc pas dâ€™avoir agi ainsiâ€¦ Â»
Un bÃ¢timent du Parlement europÃ©en Ã  Bruxelles portant le nom de Sophie Scholl. Â© Dpa/pa Le 22 fÃ©vrier 1943, Sophie et Hans Scholl ainsi que Christoph Probst furent condamnÃ©s Ã  mort par le Volksgerichtshof et exÃ©cutÃ©s le mÃªme jour. Quant aux trois autres membres de la Rose blanche, leur exÃ©cution eut lieu le 19 avril. Certaines personnes qui les soutenaient furent condamnÃ©es Ã  de lourdes peines de prison. Aujourdâ€™hui, Sophie Scholl, assassinÃ©e Ã  lâ€™Ã¢ge de 21 ans, et ses camarades de lutte sont devenus des modÃ¨les pour les gens du monde entier.

author: AFP
title: Pour la militante Ã©cologiste Sage Lenier, "l'IA n'apporte aucun avantage Ã  la sociÃ©tÃ©"
text: Pour la militante Ã©cologiste Sage Lenier, "l'IA n'apporte aucun avantage Ã  la sociÃ©tÃ©" Â© Patricia DE MELO MOREIRA, AFP - La militante amÃ©ricaine pour l'environnement Sage Lenier, fondatrice de Sustainable & Just Future, lors d'un entretien en marge du Web Summit Ã  Lisbonne (du 11 au 14 novembre 2024). Les entreprises technologiques ne cessent de promouvoir des produits avec de l'intelligence artificielle (IA) mais cette technologie est "inutile", non durable, et a crÃ©Ã© "une crise existentielle" pour le secteur, affirme la militante pour l'environnement, Sage Lenier. Un discours qui dÃ©tonne au sein du Web Summit, qui rÃ©unit Ã  Lisbonne le gratin des start-up et investisseurs dans les nouvelles technologies. "L'IA n'apporte aucun avantage Ã  la sociÃ©tÃ©", assÃ¨ne l'AmÃ©ricaine, lors d'un entretien avec l'AFP en marge du sommet. Les grands patrons ont Ã©tÃ© sÃ©duits pour des produits "inutiles", abandonnant l'idÃ©e que la technologie doit avoir une utilitÃ© fondamentale, et maintenant ils font face Ã  "une crise existentielle", soutient celle qui s'est fait connaÃ®tre en 2018, Ã  19 ans, lorsqu'elle a crÃ©Ã© un cours Ã  l'universitÃ© de Berkeley (Californie), intitulÃ© "Solutions pour un futur juste et durable", auquel des centaines d'Ã©tudiants se sont inscrits. Sage Lenier a depuis fondÃ© une association sur le mÃªme thÃ¨me ("Sustainable & Just Future") et espÃ¨re en tirer une sÃ©rie documentaire. "Certains d'entre vous peuvent Ãªtre considÃ©rÃ©s comme Ã©tant les architectes, directement responsables, de la crise Ã©cologique", avait-elle lancÃ© l'an dernier aux entrepreneurs lors de son intervention au Web Summit. Elle avait plaidÃ© pour que l'Ã©conomie circulaire, qui consiste Ã  mettre en avant le recyclage et le rÃ©emploie, soit au coeur de la dÃ©marche des patrons de la "tech", dont les produits finissent souvent Ã  la poubelle, alimentant le gaspillage. Appel peu entendu puisque les gÃ©ants Microsoft, Google et consorts continuent Ã  produire un flux ininterrompu de produits dopÃ©s Ã  l'IA, technologie extrÃªmement Ã©nergivore, ce qui semble mettre en pÃ©ril la rÃ©alisation de leurs objectifs de neutralitÃ© carbone. Pour assurer leurs besoins croissants en Ã©lectricitÃ©, notamment ceux de leurs centres de stockage de donnÃ©es, ces mastodontes se tournent ainsi de plus en plus vers le nuclÃ©aire. - "GÃ¢chis d'Ã©missions" - L'intelligence artificielle "est terrible pour la planÃ¨te. C'est terrible pour les populations qui vivent lÃ  oÃ¹ on implante des centres de donnÃ©es. C'est juste un gÃ¢chis d'Ã©missions (carbone)", fustige Sage Lenier. Le secteur de la "tech" est pourtant "la seule industrie, du moins en AmÃ©rique, qui a essayÃ© pendant des annÃ©es de se prÃ©senter comme verte, propre et pro-avenir", selon l'activiste. Et de rappeler que Bill Gates, cofondateur de Microsoft, "a Ã©crit plusieurs livres sur le changement climatique". Les titans de la "teche tiennent Ã  cette image et ont rÃ©ussi Ã  Ã©viter jusqu'Ã  prÃ©sent l'attention et les polÃ©miques sur les questions Ã©cologiques que peuvent connaÃ®tre l'industrie de la mode ou le secteur automobile, pour Mme Lenier. "Mais dÃ¨s qu'ils ont vu les opportunitÃ©s avec l'IA d'augmenter les profits des actionnaires, ils ont tous foncÃ©", dit-elle. Avec l'essor de l'intelligence artificielle, combinÃ©e Ã  l'impact des autres industries, Sage Lenier prÃ©voit un futur sombre. "La situation va se dÃ©grader trÃ¨s rapidement. La chaÃ®ne alimentaire va se briser. Nous assisterons Ã  une malnutrition de masse voire une famine de masse", alerte-t-elle. Le rÃ©seau Ã©lectrique devrait aussi cÃ©der. " Vous ne pouvez pas avoir de voitures sur le long terme. Peu importe qu'elles soient Ã©lectriques ou non. Elles ne sont pas durables". "Nous ne pouvons pas continuer Ã  produire 80 milliards de vÃªtements par an dans un futur bas carbone", poursuit la jeune femme. publiÃ© le 15 novembre Ã  13h32, AFP
